page.title: 18TRANSPORT
page.content: The traffic problem that exists in Bath is a common one for historic towns whose roads and streets were built long before the motor car was dreamt of. This together with the lack of foresight of planners has added to the situation. Following the SECOND WORLD WAR a golden oportunity existed to rebuild those areas destroyed by German bombs. The ABERCROMBIE plan was put forwars but rejected. In the 1960's the BUCHANAN plan attempted to deal with the traffic problem by suggesting that a tunnel be dug to carry passing traffic under the city. Today much debate has surrounded the BATHEASTON bypass which aims to divert all the south coast traffic away from the city.This plan is due to start before the end of the decade. Meanwhile the traffic in Bath continues to harm the envirnment.
